author: augusttrip2019
body:
Reposting here: you’re missing the point of his bet.

People don't see the full idea behind Michael Burry's TSLA short. Every single article is about how he tweeted at papa Musk and how he thinks that the company is the worst thing since he dropped his glass eye into his cat's litter box.

He doesn't think that Tesla will implode. He doesn't think it's a failing company. He just sees the reality, which is that all of their profits/revenues are way in the future.

Let's just say you win a time-delayed lottery and get $1,000,000 in 15 years. Not bad! Now let's say you won the same lottery in Venezuela in 2005. It's not even worth cashing the ticket.

It's the same deal with companies. Growth companies, however promising, have most of their expected profits in the future. Those profits have to be discounted by the **interest rate** to be turned into todays dollars. In other words, it doesn't matter how much money Tesla is going to make in the future if interest rates surge today. Well... it does matter... it's just worth a lot less.

So how does this relate to the Burry bet? You just have to scroll down a few lines on his 13F filing.

Burry has almost as many GOOG/FB calls as he does TSLA puts. Around \~$330MM of them. Why does this matter? These are big tech companies that are actually printing out metric shit-tons of profit today.

Interest rates stay the same but big tech goes up? Break even. Big tech goes down? Break even. Interest rates rise? Burry makes more money in a year than all of your wives boyfriends combined.

TL;DR:

The Burry TSLA short isn't a bet against Tesla, it's a bet on interest rates rising (AKA inflation).

author: Daegoba
body:
I wouldn’t hold more than 6 months of monthly expenses in cash. The rest, I would spread over the safest, most fucking boring ass ETFs I could, some well-established stocks, a few index funds, and me? I’d “gamble” with maybe 5% on good potential up-and-coming companies in industries that show a strong promise of growth and expansion.

You have to have an emergency fund. There’s simply no telling what can happen day to day, and risking your livelihood just isn’t an option nowadays. I just got hit by a car 6 weeks ago and am unable to work. Luckily, I had an emergency fund to cover my bills or I would be colossally FUCKED.  $15-20k in cash is not going to make you rich invested over decades. Why risk it? It’s worth more if it’s kept close to insulate you in case of unforeseen circumstances. It simply doesn’t make sense not to. 

Fidelity, Vanguard, & TD all offer their own (as well as assess to) any and all small return/low risk ishares type shit to park good money in. They’re a great option to have as far as “safe” plays that will mostly keep pace with the markets and still not over leverage you as far as risk. 

The well-established individual stocks will always be a good play so long as you don’t get caught up in every little detail of day-to-day pricing. Anything in the top 20 of the S&P will keep you right on pace with the greater economy, and give you some security and reassurance that you’re getting the most out of your money. 

The “gambling” is what will keep you interested, educated, and give you potentially the most bang for your buck. I’m not talking about YOLO’s into some Foreign penny stock. I’m talking about common-sense plays that’s anyone who doesn’t have their head in the sand. Electric cars. 3D printing. Green Energy. Shit like that. These are budding industries that are obviously going to grow and expand over the next decade. Which companies will rise to the top? Who the fuck knows, but it’s sure as the weather that there’s a garage out there with the next Jobs, Bezos, or Musk out there right now. Why not try to catch it, and learn a little in the process?

author: jonathan34562
body:
Please upvote this so I can answer the most common questions I am getting in one place.


1) How did I get to this point in my life?

I have a master degree in computer science and spent 8 years working as a programmer at lots of different companies.  Then I launched my own consulting company - quickly figured out that services work doesn't scale well - pivoted the business to a product startup and used the consulting to finance it.  All told, it took 20 years to get a really big exit - like net of over $200M.  
There is no shortcut that I know of - education, skills, experience,  lots of hard work for years and then luck.
Now I get to do whatever I like, I am typing this from a private jet on the wifi coming back from vacation... I know, wtf. I pinch myself too.


2) How can I invest like you?

Well. I have a lot of money so I can make risky bets.  I don't do options though, only stocks. I put $50k into GME on a whim at $65 and sold when it hit $350.  That was a laugh.  

But seriously, I invest in stocks that I feel like I know. I use HUBS - they are in a great space and really appealing to SMB. I see them as the most viable competitor to Salesforce - go look at Salesforce's market cap. Classic Clayton Christensen - you will be eaten from below.

I am not really much of an investor - just see things that make sense. I bought Amazon at $350 - should have put in more...

I typically invest in tech stocks because I feel like I understand the business.

My stock account is just my plaything. My real investing is much more structured and done with my wealth advisor at a large brokerage.

author: canadianformalwear
body:
I remember being a lurker on here years ago under a different account, and it seemed like mods would straight up ban people for a lot of the b.s. and obvious shilling that goes on now. If accounts didn’t seem legit or have valid history and people were posting fake or pump and dump DD, they’d be banned. 

But in the end some of those mods turned out to be shills themselves, and that irony isn’t lost on most of us. 

Investing has become relatively easy, and app driven especially in a rediculous bull market. 

If there’s a fiscal downturn, or stagnant markets (which have happened for years at a time) it’s going to literally wipe out the current vast majority of this sub, and things will get quieter around here for sure.

author: smr5000
body:
Coca-Cola's flavor was derived in part from

the Kola nut, which is in the cocoa family.

From *the Wikipedia*:

> The term kola nut usually refers to the seeds of certain species of plant of the genus Cola, placed formerly in the cocoa family Sterculiaceae and now usually subsumed in the mallow family Malvaceae (as subfamily Sterculioideae). These cola species are trees native to the tropical rainforests of Africa. Their caffeine-containing seeds are used as flavoring ingredients in beverages applied to various carbonated soft drinks, from which the name cola originates.[1]

author: BaronCapdeville
body:
This is the most relevant advice, OP. Adjust your holdings according to what you can afford to be vaporized. 

Also, dollar cost averaging all the way down in 2008 was the hardest thing I’ve ever done, mostly because my account was tiny then, as was my income. 

BOY am I glad I kept funneling my spare nickels and quarters into my Roth back then. They are dollars instead of coins now. 

1. Keep buying if you are able. Sell nothing if possible. 

2. Delete your trading apps and start using finviz or some other portfolio tracker. Even then, try to limit your check ins to one Day a week or less. It helps with the anxiety. 

3. Take up a strenuous, time consuming hobby like Kayaking or some such. You’ll sleep better and handle the cortisol better. Kept me sane through some rough shit. 

Good luck OP.

author: RandolphE6
body:
This is how human psychology works: 

$200: It's kinda high right now what if it goes down and I lose money? I'll wait. 

$250: Well I thought $200 was too high, $250 is definitely too high. So I'll wait for correction. 

$300: What the hell it keeps going up? Market is overpriced AF. 

$350: Omg insane overpriced. Crash is for sure imminent. 

$400: I guess markets do only go up. Fug it all in! 

... Market correction starts ... 

UGHHH I made the whole market collapse.

author: unpopulrOpini0n
body:
As cheesy as it sounds, the entire feel of the place has changed, I remember days of old, with people pumping random unknown shit stocks and we'd buy them, I remember the piss drinking, I remember calling people autist and retard and really meaning it, I remember detailed DD post that aired the day of a pump, the day before a crash, over and over, I remember theta gang having a bigger reach, I remember when we could have talks about p/e ratios, the profitability of companies that never made a profit, bubbles, and the like, all while shitting on each other in true autist fashion, sure fewer memes, but it felt like the memes that did surface had more power.


Idk man, a lot has changed, and it's fine, it happens, but I remember 600,000 degenerates, I remember 1,000,000 and then so suddenly it's at 8, and all the people and threads of conversation and pull that once were are now diluted and changing. It's life, change is the only constant.


But most of all, the internal voice I used when reading content on wsb has changed, it used to be much more vile, and I miss it.

author: Hozz8528
body: China gives land on a lease to Evergrande so they can build on. Evergrande borrows money from investors and entities and pre-sells apartment units to people who want cheap apartments to live in or flip later. Evergrande uses money to lease more land and finish some of the buildings. Evergrande decides to floor the gas pedal and all is fantastic for a while. Sometime last year, China says that Evergrande can't use the unit presale money to lease more land and puts limits on how much it can keep borrowing. Evergrande decides to pre-sell new units cheaper to keep money coming. People wake up and decide that this is fucked up and decide that they wanna cash out on their investment and new people stop buying, driving prices further down. Now nobody wants Evergrande stuff and Evergrande can't finish its projects or repay anything. People are currently speculating about how much EG owes to whom and how bad it will be for the rest of the world. That's how my ape brain understood it.

author: Remote-Boysenberry
body:
In my opinion, on a personal level no, it's probably the greatest thing the average person could do to build wealth. I encourage everyone in my family to do it, and have helped many people learn about investing and about their 401ks. I am maxing out my 401k and Roth IRA this year.

On a collective level, I think it is. So much of our futures are wrapped up in these accounts, that the way we think and perceive about policy is almost guaranteed to change. It's easy to make a big environmental push like in the 70s when the average person wasn't involved in the stock market, and if they read that Coal Factory Into Water Inc.'s stock fell due to new rules, they'd shrug. Now when the subject of regulating or reigning in big pharma, big energy, big tech, big Telco, big agra, the military industrial complex, etc... comes up, way more people are going to have reservations. 

If these titans of industry and index funds start posting bad years because of changes that objectively help people (like better food and water or safety standards), there will be public resistance to that. As another example, most Americans don't like the idea of outsourcing. But if 3M outsourcing is letting them continue to post big gains year over year, I think these new 401k investors, whose quality of life in retirement depends on market performance, are more willing to look the other way and cross their fingers and hope it's not their job that comes up on the chopping block. Once new 401k investors look at their first 401k calculator and go "Wow, if I keep putting this percentage and maybe up it a little every year, I'll have like 1.5 MM!" in their mind, they have the 1.5MM if they scrimp and save. If anything threatens that average 7-10% stock market gain every year, they're willing to change their minds about public policy to get that 1.5MM they feel they were promised. If Amazon factory workers get a new wage floor, their stock might go down, and people might notice and be affected. I think that's overall a bad thing.

On a conventional macro-economic scale, I think it must have some effect on market liquidity, volatility, interest rates, propensity to invest, overall participation in the stock market, etc... but I don't have a formal education in that area to say with any authority.

But that's basically just my political opinion, I'm a leftist in /r/investing, so what do I know.

author: Chip-Skylurk
body:
There’s a lot going on right now that contributes to why people are thinking sooner than later. There are pretty apparent staff and supply chain issues in the US right now, worse than I’ve personally seen before. Costs of goods are up. You’ve got eviction moratoriums ending, a bunch of federal unemployment benefits just ended as well. Major uncertainty going into the fall/winter surrounding COVID and any restrictions/lockdowns the government might push for, especially with the mRNA therapies not being as effective against variants as expected.

I know there are several technical indicators that point to an imminent correction, but these are just some of the not so technical things that we’re seeing first hand or will be dealing with soon. It’s hard to be to bullish right now.
